section.title: Prerequisite
section.para:
This tutorial was built on Mac 10.5, however the process should not be very different (if any) on other platforms. Also, the following must be installed and available prior to using this tutorial:
Eclipse 3.2+
Spring 2.5.4
Latest Spring DM distribution
Eclipse Spring IDE installed (Spring IDE installation page)
JDK 1.5+
Maven 2.0.7+
Also, make sure your computer is connected to the internet (for Maven dependencies)

step.title: In this section we are going to setup M2_REPO environment for our future class path
step.para: If you don't have Maven installed please refer to Maven documentation on how to install and configure Maven
Go to Preferences -> Java -> Build Path -> Classpath Variables
Click on New
Select folder and point to the location of your .m2/repository
Click OK and your M2_REPO should be set
Click OK

step.title: Create Spring DM Target Platform

para.command: Eclipse -> Preferences -> Plug-in Development -> Target Platform

step.para: The Preferences window will open up (see below)
At the bottom find a drop down list of Predefined Targets and select Spring Dynamic Modules for OSGi™ Service Platform 1.1.0.Snapshot

You should see an absolutely empty window (as above). Now we are going to set up our Target Platform by adding (deploying) Spring-DM Core bundles. The root directory for a Target Platform is shown in the Location drop-down at the top of the Preferences window (e.g. /Users/olegzhurakousky/. . ./targets/snapshot/target). We can obviously navigate to such directory via Finder/Explorer, but it would be easier to work with it if we set up a link from within the Eclipse workspace. This way we’ll be able to manage our Target Platform without leaving our IDE. To do this first create a General project:
File -> New -> Project -> General -> Project and name it OSGi-Target-Platform (or anything you want)

para.command: Right-click on the newly created project -> New -> Folder

step.para: New Folder window will open up (see below)

Enter target as Folder name. Check Link to folder in the file system and enter (browse or cut/paste) the path to the Location of Target Platform discovered in the previous step: (e.g. /Users/olegzhurakousky/. . ./targets/snapshot/target)
Now we are ready to begin deploying bundles. All we need to do is start copying them into target directory of our newly created project.

step.title: Install Spring DM Core Bundles
step.para: To install bundles we need to know where to get them. Assuming you downloaded and unpacked the latest distribution of Spring-DM project, navigate to the directory where you unpacked the Spring-DM project. Once there go to lib directory and you will see a bunch of JAR files. These are ready to be used OSGi bundles (a.k.a OSGi-fied JARs). The first bundle we are going to install is org.eclipse.osgi. This is the most essential bundle. Without it Equinox OSGi framework will not start. Copy it into target directory of OSGi-Target-Platform project we have created in the previous step.
Before we go any further let’s test and make sure that we are able to start our OSGi environment.

para.command: Right-click on the arrow beside Run icon on the menu bar and select Open Run Dialog

step.para: The Run window will open up. Navigate to OSGi Framework -> Right-click and select New

When new Configuration window opens up, name it OSGi-WEB (or anything you want, since our first bundle is not going to be web enabled) and click on Apply. You should also see the org.eclipse.osgi bundle that we’ve deployed earlier (see below). Make sure it is checked.
Click Run. You should see the console prompt: osgi> . Enter ss and you should see the message below. Make sure that the bundle state is ACTIVE.

para.programlisting:
Framework is launched.
id State Bundle 0 ACTIVE org.eclipse.osgi_3.4.0.v20080205

step.para: We’ve verified that our core OSGi environment is setup. You can shut down the OSGi platform now.

Now we are ready to deploy the rest of the bundles needed to “Spring-load” our OSGi platform. To do this we will simply repeat the step of installing bundles into our Target Platform (by copying them into target directory we've created (linked to) earlier).
Navigate back to the directory where you unpacked the Spring-DM distribution, go to dist directory and copy all JAR files into target directory of our new platform.
Also, from lib directory copy the following JARs:

literallayout.emphasis: aopalliance.osgi-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar asm.osgi-2.2.3-SNAPSHOT.jar jcl104-over-slf4j-1.4.3.jar log4j.osgi-1.2.15-SNAPSHOT.jar slf4j-api-1.4.3.jar slf4j-log4j12-1.4.3.jar spring-aop-2.5.4.jar spring-beans-2.5.4.jar spring-context-2.5.4.jar spring-context-support-2.5.4.jar spring-core-2.5.4.jar

step.para: Our Target Platform now contains all required Spring-DM bundles (see below to verify).

step.para: Open Eclipse -> Preferences -> Plug-in Development -> Target Platform and click on Reload -> OK
Next Open Run Dialog again, navigate to our OSGi configuration, make sure that all bundles are checked and click on Run
